Speaker: lao
Dialogue: Dr. Jones.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Lao She.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: Nee chin lie how ma?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Wah hung how, nee nah?  Wah hwey hung jing chee jah loo nee kao soo wah shu shu.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: You never told me you spoke my language, Dr. Jones.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I don't like to show off.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: For this special occasion, I ordered champagne and caviar.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: So, it is true, Dr. Jones?  you found Nurhachi?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Sure, I found him.  Then last night I had a little trouble. Somebody tried to slit my throat.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: You have insulted my son.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Next time I'll cut off more than his finger.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: Dr. Jones -- I want Nurhachi.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: As I recall the deal was consid- erably more.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Aren't you going to introduce us?

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: This is Willie Scott.  And this is Indiana Jones, the famous archaeologist.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well -- I thought archaeologists were always funny little men searching for their mummies --  Aaahhh!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Put the gun away, sonny.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Now I suggest you pay me what you promised -- or your girlfriend here is going to be squealing a new tune.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Try again Lao -- the deal was more.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at this!  He put a hole in my dress from Paris!

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: Sit down!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: A bonus, Dr. Jones.  That is poison.  You just drank the rest of it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This Nurhachi's a very small guy.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Inside are the remains of Nur- hachi -- the first Emperor of the Manchu Dynasty.

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: At last I have the ashes of my sacred ancestor!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: So, what's the big deal?  Let me see it --

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: You fool!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Ow, you're hurting me, you miser- able little hood!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Let go of her, Lao.  And give me the antidote.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hey, he's not a waiter...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: No, Wu Han's an old friend I brought along.  So, the game's not over. Put the antidote on the table, Lao.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Wu Han  --  listen to me  --  I'm going to get you out of here.

Speaker: wu han
Dialogue: Not this time, my friend...  I followed you on many adventures -- but into the great Unknown Mystery, I go first, Indy...

Speaker: lao
Dialogue: Don't be sad, Dr. Jones -- you will soon join him.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: The antidote -- !

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Look out, damn it, I need that antidote!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Who cares?  Where's that diamond!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Excuse me, but I believe that's my diamond!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Aw nuts!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Wow!  Holy smoke!  Crash landing!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Step on it, Short Round!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Okey doke, Indy!  Hold onto your potatoes!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: For crying out loud, a kid's driv- ing the car?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Relax, I've been giving him lessons.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Listen, we just met for crissake! I'm not that kind of gril!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Don't get your hopes up -- where's the antidote?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You don't look very good.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Poison never agrees with me.  Pull a right, Short Round, and head for the Wang Poo bridge!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Check!  Gotcha!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at what you've done to me! I'm a mess!  My lipstick's smeared, I broke two nails, I've got an aw- ful run in my stocking -- !

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Somehow I think you've got bigger problems.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What're we going to do?!  Where're we going?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: The airport...No, look out, Short Round!  Left, left!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You got the tickets, Short Round?

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Sure, Indy -- three tickets! You, me and Wu Han --

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Wu Han's not coming, Shorty.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Don't worry, Indy.  Short Round number one bodyguard now!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'll take the extra ticket.  Where's this plane going anyway?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Siam.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Siam?  But I'm not dressed for Siam...

Speaker: weber
Dialogue: No, no, they're all right! Let them through please.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Thanks, Weber.

Speaker: weber
Dialogue: Dr. Jones, this is positively the last time our airline can hold a plane for you.  Now you must hurry!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: So, what're you supposed to be, a lion tamer?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Since I was nice enough to let you tag along, why don't you give your mouth a rest?  Okay, doll?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm freezing.  What do you mean, tag along?  From the minute you walked into that nightclub, you haven't been able to keep your eyes off me.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Oh yeah?

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Lao send planes to kill Indy!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Wake up!  It's the drug he drank to stop the poison --

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You got to be kidding!  No!  No, I can't!

Speaker: kao kan
Dialogue: Jones!  Indiana Jones!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: No, can't leave Indy!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Give me that parachute, I changed my mind --

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: No, this last one!  It's for Indy!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: We there yet?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: There's nobody flying the plane!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: No.  Do you?

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Come here, lady, hold this and shut up please!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: I get it!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You got it!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Oh oh -- big mistake!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Short Round, what in the hell are you doing?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Are you crazy, a lift raft?!  We're not sinking, we're crashing!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Get over here, damn it!  Short Round, come on, grab onto me tight!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Wait for me!

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Indy?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Okay, Shorty.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No... I'm not cut out for the kind of life you lead.  Oh no...I ripped my dress.  Where are we anyway?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: India...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Holy cow -- India?  How do you know we're in --

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He told me they knew I was coming here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What do you mean -- how?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: The old man saw it in a dream.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Dream -- nightmare is more like it.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He said that's whey they were at river -- they were waiting for the plane to fall down.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I hope this means we're going to get some dinner.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They're starving, too...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I -- here, please.

Speaker: chieftain
Dialogue: You will rest here before you go on.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: We'd appreciate that.  This was an unexpected detour.  We'll have to go to Delhi now and find a flight west.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Indy is taking me to America.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I'm a professor.  I have to re- turn to the university.  Can you give us a guide to take us to Delhi?

Speaker: chieftain
Dialogue: Sanju will guide you.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: On the way to Delhi, you will stop at Pankot.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Pankot isn't on the way to Delhi.

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: You will go to palace there.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Hasn't the Pankot palace been de- serted since the Mutiny of 1857?

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: No. Now there is new Maharajah -- and palace is powerful again.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I don't understand.  What's hap- pened here?

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: The evil starts in Pankot.  Then like monsoon, it moves darkness over all country.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: What evil?

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: They came from Palace and took sivalinga from out village.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Took what?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It's a sacred stone in a shine that's supposed to protect a village.

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: It is why Krishna brought you here.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Nobody brought us here.  Our plane crashed.  We were shot down by --

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: No.  We pray to Krishna to help us find the stone.  It was Krishna who made you fall from sky -- so you can got to Pankot Palace.  To find siva- linga -- and bring back to us.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Indy, they make out plane crash? To get you here?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It's just superstition, Shorty. Like a ghost story.

Speaker: chieftain
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Was the stone very smooth?  It was probably brought here from a sacred river.

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: Long ago -- before my father's father.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: And it had three lines painted across it?  The lines represent the three levels of the universe.  I've seen stones like the one you lost.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I don't understand how losing one rock could destroy this village.  Is it really powerful?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: But why would the Maharajah take this sacred stone?

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: They say we must pray to their evil god.  We say we will not.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He says that when the sacred stone was taken the village wells dried up first and then the river stopped.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He says their crops dies and then the animals died.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: And then they took their children.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Their children?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He says one night there was a fire in the fields.  The men went to fight it.  When they came back, they heard the women crying in the darkness.  And the children were gone.

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: You will find them when you find sivlalinga.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I don't know how I can help you here.

Speaker: chieftain
Dialogue: They do not listen.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I have friends in Delhi and I will make sure they investigate this...

Speaker: shaman
Dialogue: No, you will got to Pankot...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What'd he say now?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It was destined that I came here -- and the future cannot be changed...

Speaker: little boy
Dialogue: Sankara...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Sankara...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Damn it , Willie, get on -- we've got to move out!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Whoa!  Easy now -- nice elephant...

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: I ride with you, Indy?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Nope, you got a little surprise over there, Shorty.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Oh boy!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This is the first time anybody ever cried when I left.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: They don't cry about you.  They cry about the elephants leaving.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Figures...

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: They got no food to feed them.  So they taking the elephants away to sell them.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: All right, let's go.  I want to get to Pankot before tomorrow night.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Pankot?!  I thought we were going to Delhi!  Hey, wait a minute!  Can't somebody take me to Delhi?! I don't want to go to Pankot!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I think you need this more than me.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Here you go, lunch time!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Those are very big bird.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Those aren't birds -- those are giant bats.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They must be pretty dumb to drink that awful-looking water.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I think maybe we'll camp here.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Hey, Willie -- I think you better get out now.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Stark naked?  You wish... If you're trying to seduce me, Dr. Jones, this is a very primitive approach.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Me seduce you?  Honey, you're the one who took your clothes off.  I just came over to remind you that you never know what else might be in the water.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Somehow I feel safer in here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Indy!  Help me!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'm coming in!  What is it?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: A snake!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: A what...?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: A SNAKE!!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Uh, listen -- Willie -- I got a better idea.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: First of all -- don't panic!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's got me !  Indy, help me!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Don't let it pull you deeper!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's pulling me deeper!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Don't let it curl around you!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's curling around me!  Damn it, stop talking and do something!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Listen, Willie.  Do exactly what I tell you now.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Can you move your arm?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Just one arm!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Okay, I want you to lift your hand -- and pet the snake.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: PET IT??!!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Yes, stroke it right along the maxillary and precaudal verte- brae.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: THE WHAT?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Pet it on the head!  Go on, pet it!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh -- my -- god -- it's going to crush me!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Keep stroking it!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's starting to let go!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: That's good  -- you're doing fine.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's letting fo.  I think it's -- I think it's going to sleep!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: See -- I got you out...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Thanks for nothing!  I hate snakes!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I know the feeling...

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: You come to America with me, and we can get job in the circus -- you like that?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Where'd you find your little body- guard?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I met Short Round when he tried to pick my pocket.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: He'll be okay.  He's a good kid.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: By the way, how'd you end up in Shanghai?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, when my nightclub career was run over by the Depression, some pinhead convinced me that "a girl could go places in the Orient..." So, look where I got.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: What about the future?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, that's easy -- I'm going to latch onto a good-looking, in- credibly rich prince.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I'd like to find one of those myself.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh really?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Yeah, but he's got to be dead and buried for a couple of thousand years.  Fortune and glory...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Is that what you're hoping to find at this palace, Dr. Jones?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Maybe...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Something that kid gave me last night.  It's a piece of an old manuscript.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What does the writing say?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It's Sanskrit.  It tells the story of Sankara climbing Mt. Kalisa where he met the Hindu god Shiva.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: That's Shiva?  What's he giving the Priest?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Legend says he told Sankara to go forth and combat evil.  To do that he gave him five sacred stones that had magical powers.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You mean magical like the rock that was stolen from that village?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It could be.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Fortune and glory...sweet dreams, Dr. Jones.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I think you should sleep closer.  I meant for safety.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'd be safer sleeping with that snake.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Did you see it?!  It was one of those bats!  God, what else is out there...?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Couldn't keep away, huh?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Just try and control yourself.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Still scared?  Okay, Willie, you can get closer if you want...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Honey, I knew you'd be the first one to give in...

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Indy, look!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: That's it.  Pankot Palace.

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: What you look at, Indy?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Just a statue.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's the guide talking about? He hasn't said a word the whole trip.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: He's afraid of something.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: He said he couldn't take us any farther.  He has to go sell the elephants.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You mean we have to walk the rest of the way?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: -- shot at, fallen out of a plane, nearly drowned, squashed by a snake, attacked by a bat -- I smell like an elephant!  I tell you I'm not going to make it!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Any more complaints?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yeah, I wish you'd thought of this sooner...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It doesn't feel like there's been any permanent damage.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Hello?...

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: I would say you look rather lost.  But then I cannot imagine where in the world the three of you would look at home...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Lost?  No, we're not lost.  We're on our way to Delhi.  This is Miss Scott -- and Mr. Round.  My name's Indiana Jones.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Dr. Jones?  The eminent archae- ologist?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hard to believe, isn't it...?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: I remember first hearing your name when I was studying at Oxford.  I Am Chattar Lal, Prime Minister for His Highness the Maharajah of Pankot.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How'd you like to run into him in a dark alley...that one's kind of cute...I could see myself married to a prince like that...

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: The plane crash and your journey here sound -- most incredible.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You should have been there...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: We'd appreciate it if the Mahara- jah would let us stay tonight. We'll be on out way in the morn- ing.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: I am only his humble servant, but the Maharajah usually listens to my advice.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Is that him?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: No, no, that is Uhmed Singh, the present Maharajah's late father.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh -- good.  And maybe the pres- ent Marahajah is a little younger? And thinner?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: They will escort you to your rooms now.  You will be provided with fresh clothes.  Tonight you will be dining with His Highness.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Dinner?  And with a prince?!  My luck is changing.  But look at me -- my god, I've to to get ready!

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Eight o'clock in the Pleasure Pavilion.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You look like a princess.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's sort of like being in heaven.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I've always had a weakness for folk dancing.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: She might get away with that act here, but she'd never make it in a real nightclub.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: We are fortunate tonight to have some many unexpected guests.  his is Captain Phillip Blumburtt.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: The British worry so about their Emprie -- it makes us feel like well-cared-for children.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Listen, Mr. Lal, what do you call the Maharajah's  wife?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: His Highness has not yet taken a wife.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No?  Well, I guess he just hasn't met the right woman...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: No.  But I am interested in the occult.  And this is a krtya.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: It's like the voodoo dolls of West Africa.  The kryta represents your enemy -- and gives you complete power over him.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You're hanging on better here than you did in America.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: The Prime Minister doesn't seem that naive.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I think this Maharajah is swim- ming in money.  Maybe coming here wasn't such a bad idea.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Finally!

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: His Supremem Highness, guardian of Rajput tradition -- the Maharajah of Pankot -- Zalim Singh.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: That's the Maharajah -- that kid?!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Maybe he likes older women.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Cheer up, you lost your prince, but dinner's on the way.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I've never been so hungry in my life...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: My god, sort of grusome, isn't it...?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: His Highness wants me to welcome his visitors.  Especially the renowned Dr. Jones from America.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: We are honored to be here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Suddenly I'm not so hungry...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I had a question, Mr. Prime Mini- ster.  I was examining some of the Maharajah's artifacts.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: A very fine collection of very old pieces, don't you think?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Yes, very fine.  But not all of the pieces look old.  Some were carved recently and look like images used by the Thuggees to worship the god- des Kali.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Dr. Jones, you know very well that the Thuggee cult has been dead for nearly a century.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: But you're not eating!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I uh -- had bugs for lunch.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I suppose stories of the Thuggees die hard.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: There are no stories anymore.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Well, I don't know... we came here from a small village and the peas- ants there told us that the Pankot Palace was growing powerful again -- becuase of some ancient evil.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Their stories are just fear and folklore.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Maybe.. but how do you explain The Thuggee shrine I saw right below the palace?

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: The local peasants are just as superstitious.  You're very ob- servant, Dr. Jones.  But you're beginning to worry Capt. Blum- burtt.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Give me your hat...

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm going to puke in it...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You know the villagers also claimed that this palace stole something from them.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Dr. Jones, it our country a guest does not usually insult his host.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Sorry, I thought we were just talking about folklore.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Something magical.  A sacred rock.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: There, you see, Captain.  A rock!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: When they lost this rock their fields and animals dies.  They also said their children were taken from them.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: I think that's enough  of this nonsense, Dr. Jones...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: So you have something, you know, simple -- like soup or something?

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Looks delicious!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I wanna go home...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I was dubious muself at first. Then something connected -- the village's rock and the old legend of the Sankara Stones...

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Dr. Jones, we are all vulnerable to vicious rumors.  I seem to re- member that in Honduras you were accused of being a grave robber rather than a scientist.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: The newspapers exaggerated the incident

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: And didn't the Sultan of Madagas- car threaten to cut your head off if you ever returned to his coun- try?

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: That was a misunderstanding.

Speaker: chattar lal
Dialogue: Exactly what we have here, Dr. Jones.

Speaker: maharajah
Dialogue: I have heard the terrible stories of the evil Thuggee cult...

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: I'm sorry if I've offended you.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Ah, dessert!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: Even if they were trying to scare us away, a devout Hindu would never touch meat.  Makes you wonder what these people are...

Speaker: maharajah
Dialogue: I have seen this thing.  What is it, Dr. Jones?

Speaker: short round
Dialogue: Hey, nobody touches Indy's whip!

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: We're guests here, Shorty.

Speaker: maharajah
Dialogue: You will show me how it works please.

Speaker: indiana
Dialogue: You wish is my command, your Highness.
